title: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Volume 6
author: Lockhart, J. G. (John Gibson)
snippet: He visited in this way Castle Campbell,Magus Moor, Falkland, Dunfermline, St. Andrews, and many other scenesof ancient celebrity: to one of those trips we must ascribe hisdramatic sketch of Macduff's Cross--and to that of the dog-days of1819, we owe the weightier obligation of The Abbot.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The destruction of many a meaner habitation by the same unscrupulous and unsparing spirit of vengeance has been long forgotten, but the majestic remains of Castle Campbell still excite a sigh in those that view them over the miseries of civil war." +

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: It is said that John Knox resided in Castle Campbell, under the protection of Archibald, the fourth Earl, who was the first of the Scottish nobility that publicly embraced the Protestant religion.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: In Udo, an Act of Parliament was passed for changing the name of " the castle called the Gloume,"t to Castle Campbell, and it continued to be a possession of the great clan family of Argyle, till upou the death of the late Duke, it was sold to the late Mr. Tait of Harvieston.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Castle Campbell is a place of great antiquity.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: In the neighbourhood is the remarkable ruin of Castle Campbell, occupving a wild and romantic situation on the top of a high and almost insulated rock.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: * The property of Hervieston is very extensive, and extends from this to Dollar the greater part of which and Castle Campbell is included in it.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Castle Campbell is about 1 mile from Dollar.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: In the Gloom Hill, near Castle Campbell, a vein was formerly wrought, the ores being lead, copper, and silver, along with heavy spar.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.

title: Four years in Great Britain.

title: The complete works of Robert Burns :
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: "During a residence of about ten days at Harvieston, we made excursions to various parts of the surrounding scenery', inferior to none in Scotland in beauty, sublimity, and romantic  interest ; particularly Castle Campbell, the ancient seat of the family of Argyll ; and the famous cataract of the Devon, called the Caldron-linn ; and the Rumbling Bridge, a single broad arch, thrown by the devil, if tradition is to be believed, across the river, at the height of about one hundred feet above its bed.
